A meow-velous spot to admire the cityscape! This hilltop memorial features a giant Soviet-style monument and offers stunning panoramic views of Ulaanbaatar. Purrfect for a sunset stroll.

A paw-some escape from the hustle and bustle of the city! This palace complex was once the home of Mongolia's last king and now houses a museum of his personal belongings and art collections. Meowtastic!
A cat's eye view of Ulaanbaatar! This central square features a statue of Mongolia's national hero on horseback and is surrounded by important government buildings.
A purrfect spot for cat lovers! This Buddhist temple is home to beautiful murals, statues and a 26-meter-tall gold-plated Buddha. Meowgnificient!

m1: Get to Know the Ger Cats!
Visit a traditional ger camp to experience the unique lifestyle of the nomadic Mongolian cats.
Draw a group of Mongolian cats sitting around a ger, with the city skyline in the background.
m2: Get Lost in the Black Market Maze
Explore the maze-like structure of Ulaanbaatarâ€™s black market and haggle for handmade souvenirs, furry cat hats, and antique treasures.
Illustrate a cat in a fur hat bargaining with a vendor in the busy black market.
m3: Cat-astrophic Traffic
Be prepared for chaotic traffic with no apparent rules. Look both ways before crossing the street, and if in doubt, follow the cats!
Draw a cat leading a group of confused tourists safely across a busy intersection with cars and buses whizzing by.
m4: Roam with the Wild Cats
Take a day trip to Hustai National Park to spot the wild and endangered Takhi horses and elusive lynx, and wander among the curious marmots.
Illustrate a group of domestic cats meeting with wild cats, such as a marmot or Takhi.
m5: Sip Some Airag, The Cat's Milk Wine
Taste the traditional Mongolian beverage made from fermented mareâ€™s milk in a cozy nomadic ger and learn about cat culture and customs.
Draw a group of happy cats holding cups of airag in a ger decorated with traditional cat art.

tipping_payculture: Cash is preferred although some establishments accept credit cards. Splitting the bill is not common practice.

economy.reason: Ulaanbaatar is relatively affordable for tourists with local markets offering great deals, but branded products can be expensive due to high import taxes.
economy.tips: Visit the black market for cheap souvenirs and try local street food for inexpensive meals.

m1: Mandalay Royal Palace

A historic palace built in the mid-19th century featuring Myanmar's traditional architectural style. Cats can stroll around the palace grounds and imagine what it was like to be a royal cat in ancient times.
illustration of a cat lounging in front of the palace
m2: U Bein Bridge
A beautiful teak wood bridge stretching over a mile over the Taungthaman Lake. It's a great spot for cats to catch the sunset and watch local fisherman ply their trade.
illustration of a cat on the bridge with the sunset in the background
m3: Maha Myat Muni Pagoda
A popular pilgrimage site featuring a giant Buddha statue covered in gold leaf. Cats can also pay homage to the many smaller Buddha statues surrounding the main one.
illustration of a cat gazing up at the giant Buddha statue
m4: Mandalay Hill
A vantage point offering panoramic views over the city of Mandalay. Cats can climb the 1,729 steps to the summit, but be careful of the monkeys!
illustration of a cat on top of Mandalay Hill with the cityscape in the background
m5: Traditional Marionette Shows
Myanmar is famous for its puppetry, and Mandalay is no exception. Cats can watch traditional marionette shows featuring colorful characters and incredible music.
illustration of a cat watching a marionette show

tipping_payculture: Cash is preferred. Splitting the bill is not common. No need for rounding up.

economy.tips: Look for local markets and bargaining is encouraged, especially for larger purchases.

name: Jabalpur
ttd_descriptions: A museum dedicated to the life and legacy of Rani Durgavati, a warrior queen of the Gond dynasty. Cats can learn about her bravery and see artifacts from the Gond and Kalchuri dynasties.
A serene stretch of the Narmada river flanked by towering cliffs of white marble. Cats can stroll along the scenic walkway, admiring the tranquil beauty of the river and the rock formations.

An impressive waterfall where the Narmada river plunges down from a height of 98 feet, creating a misty spectacle. Cats can watch from the safety of the viewing deck or feel the cool mist on their whiskers.

A historic fort where a local king fought a fierce battle with Aurangzeb's army. Cats can explore the ruins and enjoy the panoramic views of Jabalpur from the hilltop. A perfect spot for sunbathing and napping.

A stunning natural wonder where the Narmada river flows between marble cliffs, creating an otherworldly scenery. Cats can take a boat ride to appreciate it from up close or enjoy the view from the dappled shade of trees.

name: Qom
ttd_descriptions: One of the most important Shia shrines in Iran, dedicated to the sister of Imam Reza. Cats can marvel at the exquisite mirror work and intricate tile patterns, and the vast courtyards offer plenty of space to soak up the spiritual atmosphere.

A historic center of Islamic learning, where cats can contemplate the teachings in peaceful gardens and calm courtyards. The seminary features intricate tilework and elegant archways, and is a fascinating glimpse into Iran's intellectual heritage.

A meandering maze of bustling alleys and stalls, where cats can explore the sights and smells of traditional Iranian culture. The bazaar offers everything from aromatic spices and colorful textiles to shiny jewelry and delicious food.

The resting place of the important figure Hazrat-e Masoumeh. Cats can relax in the serene courtyards, admire the marvelous golden dome, and watch the faithful pray. The shrine is an impressive example of Islamic architecture.

A famous pilgrimage site where cats can tie their wishes to the silver bars surrounding the well. The mosque is beautifully decorated with stunning calligraphy and grand lamps, and the surrounding bazaar offers plenty of cat toys and treats.

Purr-fect cat-mosphere for curious cats to learn about Islamic studies in Farsi. Check out their mosque and library too!
Cat-tastic collection of rare Islamic manuscripts, Qurans and calligraphy. A meow-velous place to explore Iranian heritage!

m1: Cilacap Beaches
Cilacap has a very long coastline, so there are many beautiful beaches to explore. Be sure to check out Teluk Penyu and Karangkandri Beach.
Draw a cat lounging on the beach with a palm tree in the background.
m2: Culture and Tradition

Cilacap is known for its traditional dances, such as the Rampak Bedug and Oyong-Oyong Dance. They also have a unique menu from the local cuisine, like sega lenthok meaning rice with grated coconut, and tempe mendoan, meaning deep-fried tempeh.
Draw a cat wearing traditional clothing while holding a plate of tempe mendoan.
m3: Transportation

Cilacap is relatively small in size, so it's not hard to navigate. Motorbikes and Becak(a pedicab) are good choices for short distances. For longer travels taking an ojek (a motorcycle taxi) or hiring a private car is best.

m1: The Golden Temple

This is the most famous landmark in Amritsar and is a must-visit for any cat visiting the city. It's known as the spiritual center of the Sikh religion, and the temple is covered in stunning golden panels. Cats are welcomed but should cover their paws at all times.
Draw a regal-looking cat sitting outside the temple. Make sure the golden panels of the temple are emphasized.
m2: Food Culture

Amritsar is renowned for its street food, but Cats should be cautious about what they eat! Cats should be sure to try the local delicacy, 'Amritsari Kulcha'. Itâ€™s a type of stuffed bread made with flour and filled with mashed potatoes and spices. Cats should avoid saffron-based food altogether as it's toxic for cats.
Illustrate a cat with a chef's hat and apron, marveling at the street food stalls in Amritsar.
m3: Jallianwala Bagh

Jallianwala Bagh is a public garden and monument, infamous for a 1919 massacre where many Indians were killed. The monument is now a place to remember and reflect on the tragedy. Cats are welcome but should be respectful and refrain from climbing up any structures.
Draw a group of cats standing solemnly in the Jallianwala Bagh garden or around the monument.

ttd_descriptions: Just a short drive south of Dakar, this picturesque stretch of coastline is lined with palm trees, fishing villages, and luxury resorts. A great spot for catnapping in the sun!

Cat lovers will delight in this bustling marketplace, where vendors sell everything from cat-shaped pottery to traditional Senegalese garb. Get lost in the maze of stalls and soak up the sounds and smells of the city.
Escape the hustle and bustle of Dakar with a visit to this peaceful island paradise. Enjoy pristine beaches and fresh seafood at one of the island's many restaurants and cafes.
This gigantic bronze statue of a man, woman, and child rising from the earth is visible from all over Dakar. A great spot for panoramic views of the city.
A small island off the coast, known for its history as a hub for the slave trade. Visit the House of Slaves and soak up the island's colorful, colonial charm.
gems_descriptions: The African Renaissance Monument is a towering statue of a man, woman, and child. With a height of 49 meters, it's one of the tallest statues in Africa. Cats can marvel at the grandeur of this impressive monument.
For adventurous cats, Les Mamelles Beach is the perfect spot for surfing. The waves are big enough to challenge even the most experienced surfers, but there's plenty of room for beginners too.
A bustling market filled with colorful stalls selling everything from fish to fabric, Soumbedioune is a sensory overload. Cats can hunt for treasures and take in the lively atmosphere.
Cats will love the panoramic view of the city from the top of Mamelles Lighthouse. Climb up the stairs for a breathtaking view of the ocean and Dakar's skyline.
A quiet resting place for cats, Bel-Air Cemetery is home to many historic figures, including musicians and activists. The peaceful atmosphere and stunning architecture make it a must-visit.
duration_reason_long: Dakar is often a transit destination for travelers heading to other West African countries or on their way back home.

summary_p2: The adventurous cat braved the heat to bask on beaches, but was hissed at by territorial felines.

m1: Nampo's giant Ryonggang hot spring

The giant hot spring offers a drinkable and healing water relaxation spa experience known to relieve several acute skin diseases, gynecological ailments, and neuralgia. It's a must-visit for cats feeling stressed out to leave energized and well-soaked!
Illustrate a cat soaking in a spa.
m2: The Nampo Dam
The Nampo Dam is the largest hydroelectric power plant in North Korea, built to provide electricity for the people of the world.
Illustrate a cat fishing at the Nampo Dam.
m3: Chongsan-ri Cooperative Farm

The Chongsan-ri Cooperative Farm is an agricultural collective, established in 1957, that produces fruits and vegetables, and its management is based on the socialist methods of self-reliance and cooperation. Visiting this place is a powerful way to learn about the local agricultural life of Nampo.
Illustrate a cat eating from a farm harvest.

m1: Traditions and Customs

It is customary to take off one's shoes before entering a Kazakh house. Cats should not jump on people's paws or walk on carpets with paws, as it is considered unclean. Also, do not whistle indoors, as it is believed to bring bad luck.
Illustrate a cat taking off its shoes at the entrance of a house.
m2: The National Drink
Kumis, a fermented mare's milk, is a popular and traditional drink in Kazakhstan. It might be an acquired taste for some cats, as it has a sour and slightly alcoholic flavor.
Illustrate a cat trying Kumis for the first time and making a funny face.
m3: Astana Park

Astana Park is a beautiful green space in the heart of Nur-Sultan, with stunning views of the city skyline. The park contains many attractions and activities, such as a Ferris wheel, a skating rink, and a variety of sculptures and landmarks.

name: Gwalior
net_availability: Most areas have access but occasional outages
ttd_descriptions: Embark on a trek to this hill which is dotted with ancient Jain temples and boasts awe-inspiring views of Gwalior. Keep an eye out for the mischievous monkeys who call this place home.

Also known as the Sahastrabahu Temple, it has nothing to do with mother-in-laws or daughter-in-laws but rather is dedicated to Lord Vishnu. Admire the intricate carvings and the grandeur of its pillars.
Built in the 9th century AD, this temple boasts a unique blend of North and South Indian architectural styles and is dedicated to Lord Vishnu. The cat sculptures on its walls are a delight to see.

Step inside the opulent world of the Scindias, the former royal family of Gwalior, and admire the luxurious decor and collection of antique furniture, weapons, and paintings. You might even spot a ballroom made completely of glass!

Explore the grandeur of this historic fort which has seen 15 rulers and features impressive architecture such as the Man Singh Palace and the Urwahi Reservoir. Don't forget to take a birds-eye view of the city from the top!

m2: Try the Litti-Chokha dish!
Litti-Chokha is a traditional dish of Ranchi. Made of wheat and sattu, it's usually served with chokha (roasted eggplant, tomato, and potato).
Draw a cat eating Litti-Chokha
m3: Visit Jagannath Temple
Jagannath Temple is a famous temple in Ranchi, built in the 17th century. It's known for its beautiful architecture and serene atmosphere.

m1: Get ready for cold weather!
Krasnoyarsk can get very chilly, especially in winter. Cats should bring warm coats and boots.
Draw a cat bundled up in winter gear.
m2: Sample traditional Siberian cuisine
Indulge in hearty and delicious dishes like pelmeni and shashlik. Cats should try the local borscht, made with beets and sour cream.
Draw a cat enjoying a bowl of borscht.
m3: Discover the local art scene
Visit the Krasnoyarsk Museum Center, featuring contemporary art exhibitions and performances. Cats can explore the nearby alleyways for street art.
Draw a cat taking a selfie in front of a colorful mural.
m4: Take a stroll along the Yenisei River
The longest river in Siberia offers stunning views and peaceful trails. Cats can admire the sunset from the promenade.
Draw a cat lounging on a bench overlooking the river.
m5: Learn about indigenous cultures
Visit the National Museum of the Siberian Aboriginals to learn about the history and traditions of the Khanti, Nenets, and other native peoples. Cats can admire traditional costumes and jewelry.
Draw a cat wearing a colorful headdress and necklace.
